areaDesc.5: Infiltration of people of lower living standards; from Colbrook to Michigan Street hill is having marked effect on property values.

areaDesc.5: A very mixed area; little developed. Some very poor construction-some fairly good. Area is attractive topographically, but future is completely uncertain.

areaDesc.5: Many rentals in this section.

1.c: Mixture of older and poorer buildings.

areaDesc.5: Old and newer types combined with older types predominating. A clean district. Pride of ownership exhibited. Some trend to conersion to multiple use.

areaDesc.5: Sparsely settled. Premature development; will probably slowly improve.

areaDesc.5: Distance of about eight miles from center of Grand Rapids. Has one industry employment about 200. Majority of inhabitants are dependent upon Grand Rapids for employment. Present construction sufficient to establish future trend of small frames with modern convenineces

1.c: Incplete city facilitates. Distance from the ccenter of the city.
1.b: Schools are good. Low taxes. New grade and high schools. Transportation facilities are satisfacotry.

areaDesc.5: An attractive, well integrated section that will probably continue to grow in favor.

1.c: Distance from center of the city. Lack of complete city facilities.
1.b: Low taxes.
Low taxes. Convenient to many industries. All city facilities. Good schools.

a.1: One family units: 5-6 rooms, bungalows, Dutch Colonials, etc.

areaDesc.5: High School, etc. located in area. A cheap but stable area for laboring men.

1.b: Undeveloped.

areaDesc.5: A few small scatered collections of miscellaneous houses. Future development a long way off, and problematically as to type.

1.c: No sewers or city water. May spread from the General Motors plant. Construction is cheap.
1.b: Adjacent to the General Motors Plant. Facilities: electricity and gas.

areaDesc.5: For the most part, this is an area of very cheap development, far from the center of town and lacking facilities. It was apparently doomed to failure until the large General Motors Stamping plant was finished in 1936. On the average, this plant employs about 2,000 and has given the section a new lease on life.

1.c: Main line Michigan Central R.R. No sewers or water. Outside the city limits.
1.b: Restricted. Near main highway. Good transportation by automobile. Good school facilities.

areaDesc.5: Many of inhabitants are of Dutch descent. Type of construction is somewhat better west of Division Street. Restrictions will probably be maintained and the area should continue to be built up slowly with good class of moderate priced homes. Water supply to the General Motors plant may help.

1.b: Undeveloped

areaDesc.5: A few small scattered collections of miscellaneous houses. Future development a long way off, and problematically as to type.

1.b: Good transportation and good schools. All city facilities.

areaDesc.5: Fulton Street is the dividing line between "southeast" and "northeast". Many old large singles have been converted to doubles. Some large, good modern single residences still remain on Lafayette, College and Prospect.

areaDesc.5: This is not by any means a "slum" area. Adjacence to Kelvinator plant makes it desirable as a residence for their employees. Also, convenient for Railroad employees and others. This section almost rates a "C" grade.

1.c: School closed for lack of pupils.
1.b: All city facilities. Convenient to large furniture factories. High ground. Well wooded. Out of smoke zone.

areaDesc.5: A small section lying on top of a hill. Isolated, and apparently a failure. A good modern school has been closed for lack of pupils.

1.b: All city facilities. Schools and transportation are good.
